maml:description.maml:para: Adds a new member (network adapter) to a specified NIC team.
The Add-NetLbfoTeamMember cmdlet adds a new network adapter as a member to the specified team. You can use the AdministrativeMode parameter to specify the initial role of the new team member.
Specifies the name (Interface Alias or Connection Name) of the network adapter to add.
Specifies the name of the NIC team to which to add the new network adapter.
Specifies the initial role of the new member (network adapter).
You can specify one of the following two status options:
Active: Allows the team member to participate in the NIC team. By default, the initial role of the team member is Active.
Standby: Places the member in a standby state where it does not participate in the team. The team member will be automatically moved to Active state if any other member of the team fails.
At most one member in a team can be in Standby mode.

Runs the cmdlet as a background job. Use this parameter to run commands that take a long time to complete. The cmdlet immediately returns an object that represents the job and then displays the command prompt. You can continue to work in the session while the job completes. To manage the job, use the *-Job cmdlets. To get the job results, use the Receive-Job cmdlet. For more information about Windows PowerShell® background jobs, see about_Jobs.

Runs the cmdlet in a remote session or on a remote computer. Enter a computer name or a session object, such as the output of a New-CimSession or Get-CimSession cmdlet. The default is the current session on the local computer.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of 0 is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
Specifies the initial role of the new member (network adapter).
You can specify one of the following two status options:
Active: Allows the team member to participate in the NIC team. By default, the initial role of the team member is Active.
Standby: Places the member in a standby state where it does not participate in the team. The team member will be automatically moved to Active state if any other member of the team fails.
At most one member in a team can be in Standby mode.

Runs the cmdlet as a background job. Use this parameter to run commands that take a long time to complete. The cmdlet immediately returns an object that represents the job and then displays the command prompt. You can continue to work in the session while the job completes. To manage the job, use the *-Job cmdlets. To get the job results, use the Receive-Job cmdlet. For more information about Windows PowerShell® background jobs, see about_Jobs.

Runs the cmdlet in a remote session or on a remote computer. Enter a computer name or a session object, such as the output of a New-CimSession or Get-CimSession cmdlet. The default is the current session on the local computer.
Specifies the name (Interface Alias or Connection Name) of the network adapter to add.
Specifies the name of the NIC team to which to add the new network adapter.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of 0 is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
This cmdlet takes no input objects.
This cmdlet returns an array of MSFT_NetLbfoTeamMember objects consisting of the newly added member network adapter objects to the team.

command:example.maml:title: Example 1: Add a new team member

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command adds a new member named NIC1 to the specified team named Team1.

command:example.maml:title: Example 2: Add a new team member with initial status
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Add-NetLbfoTeamMember -Name NIC2 -Team Team2 -AdministrativeMode Standby

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command adds a new member named NIC2 to the specified team named Team2 with the initial status Standby.

command:example.maml:title: Example 3: Add new team members using wildcard pattern

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command adds new members whose name starts with NIC to the specified team named Team1.

maml:description.maml:para: Retrieves a list of network adapters that are members of a NIC team, as specified by the input parameters.

The Get-NetLbfoTeamMember cmdlet retrieves the list of all network adapters (team members) of all NIC teams. You can also use Get-NetLbfoTeamMember to retrieve a list of network adapters for the specified NIC team, and then use that information as input to the other cmdlets.
Specifies the name (or wildcard pattern of the name) of a team member whose details need to be retrieved.

Specifies the NIC team name (or wildcard pattern) for which the user wants to enumerate the members. If no team parameter is present, it returns all members specified by Name parameter from all teams on the system.

Runs the cmdlet as a background job. Use this parameter to run commands that take a long time to complete. The cmdlet immediately returns an object that represents the job and then displays the command prompt. You can continue to work in the session while the job completes. To manage the job, use the *-Job cmdlets. To get the job results, use the Receive-Job cmdlet. For more information about Windows PowerShell® background jobs, see about_Jobs.

Runs the cmdlet in a remote session or on a remote computer. Enter a computer name or a session object, such as the output of a New-CimSession or Get-CimSession cmdlet. The default is the current session on the local computer.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of 0 is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.

To manage the job, use the *-Job cmdlets. To get the job results, use the Receive-Job cmdlet. For more information about Windows PowerShell® background jobs, see about_Jobs.

If this parameter is omitted or a value of 0 is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.

Runs the cmdlet in a remote session or on a remote computer. Enter a computer name or a session object, such as the output of a New-CimSession or Get-CimSession cmdlet. The default is the current session on the local computer.
Specifies the name (or wildcard pattern of the name) of a team member whose details need to be retrieved.

Specifies the NIC team name (or wildcard pattern) for which the user wants to enumerate the members. If no team parameter is present, it returns all members specified by Name parameter from all teams on the system.
Specifies the NIC team object whose associated member objects are to be retrieved.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of 0 is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.
This cmdlet takes no input objects.
This cmdlet produces an array of MSFT_NetLbfoTeamMember objects corresponding to the query.

command:example.maml:title: Example 1: Get a list of team members

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command retrieves a list of team members for the specified NIC team named Team1.

command:example.maml:title: Example 2: Get a list of all team members

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command retrieves a list of all team members of all NIC teams on the system.

command:example.maml:title: Example 3: Get a list of all team members via associations
command:example.dev:code:
PS C:\> Get-NetLbfoTeam –Name Team1 | Get-NetLbfoTeamMember
Or PS C:\> $teamObj = Get-NetLbfoTeam –Name Team1 PS C:\> Get-NetLbfoTeamMember –TeamOfTheMember $teamObj

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command retrieves a list of all team members belonging to team named Team1.

maml:description.maml:para: Removes one or more network adapters from a specified NIC team.

The Remove-NetLbfoTeamMember cmdlet removes one or more network adapters from the specified NIC team. You must specify at least one network adapter to remove from the team. In order to remove the last team member of a team, you must remove the team by using the Remove-NetLbfoTeam cmdlet.
You need administrator privileges to use Remove-NetLbfoTeamMember.

Runs the cmdlet as a background job. Use this parameter to run commands that take a long time to complete. The cmdlet immediately returns an object that represents the job and then displays the command prompt. You can continue to work in the session while the job completes. To manage the job, use the *-Job cmdlets. To get the job results, use the Receive-Job cmdlet. For more information about Windows PowerShell® background jobs, see about_Jobs.

Runs the cmdlet in a remote session or on a remote computer. Enter a computer name or a session object, such as the output of a New-CimSession or Get-CimSession cmdlet. The default is the current session on the local computer.
Returns an object representing the item with which you are working. By default, this cmdlet does not generate any output.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.
Specifies the object which contains the team member to remove.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
Specifies the name of the team member to remove. Specify multiple team member names separated by a comma.
Specifies the name of the NIC team from which to remove the member.

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command removes the team member named NIC1 from the specified team named Team1.

maml:description.maml:para: Sets the role of a member network adapter in a NIC team.

The Set-NetLbfoTeamMember cmdlet sets the role of a specified network adapter (team member) in the NIC team. You can specify the team member either by specifying the name or by specifying the network adapter object retrieved using the Get-NetLbfoTeamMember cmdlet.
You need administrative privileges to use Set-NetLbfoTeamMember.
Specifies the name of the team member to modify.
Specifies the name of the NIC team which contains the network adapter to modify.
Specifies the administrative mode of the network adapter to modify.
You can specify one of the following two administrative modes:
Active: Allows the team member to participate in the NIC team. By default, the role of the team member is Active.
Standby: Places the member in a standby state where it does not participate in the team. The team member will be automatically moved to Active state if any other member of the team fails.
At most one member in a team can be in Standby mode.

Runs the cmdlet as a background job. Use this parameter to run commands that take a long time to complete. command:parameter.maml:name: Name

maml:description.maml:para: Specifies the name of the team member to modify.

command:parameter.dev:defaultValue: All members adapters across all teams

command:example.maml:title: Example 1: Set the team member role

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command sets the administrative mode of the specified team member named NIC4 to Standby.
